In the UK, knotweed disclosure is mandatory on all deeds of sale and one cannot obtain a mortgage if the plant is found within a certain number of meters from a residence. text:
I am a great lover of plants which I believe to be the cornerstone of life on
this planet. However, fallopia japonica, or Japanese knotweed, is listed by
the World Conservation Union as one of the world's most invasive species.

Wikipedia notes that "[t]he invasive root system and strong growth can damage
concrete foundations, buildings, flood defenses, roads, paving, retaining
walls, and architectural sites." It forms monocultures that completely exclude
native species and destroys habitats for local plants and animals and degrades
water quality.

The plant is a herbaceous perennial that is a member of the buckwheat family
that was introduced to the western world in the mid to late 1800s for its
ornamental value. In hindsight, no one should have introduced this plant. Its
spread in the United Kingdom has been so pernicious that it is deemed a
"controlled waste" which needs to be disposed of in accordance with law.

In the UK, knotweed disclosure is mandatory on all deeds of sale and one
cannot obtain a mortgage if the plant is found within a certain number of
meters from a residence. Wikipedia notes that it cost 70 million pounds to
eradicate knotweed from 10 acres of the London 2012 Olympic Games velodrome
and aquatic center.

Japanese knotweed has become a fertile field of civil litigation in the UK
with buyers fighting sellers, homeowners fighting contractors and neighbors
fighting neighbors (Henry Grabar, [Slate.com](http://Slate.com)).

The success of the plant is due to a number of factors. It can survive a wide
range of soil types, light (semi-shade and sun), pH and temperatures. It can
suppress the growth of competitor plants by releasing toxic chemicals.
However, its most fundamental advantage is its rhizome system which can grow
10 feet deep and 23 feet wide (Wikipedia).

"In addition, fragments of both stem and root material can sprout, giving rise
to new plants or entire colonies. Knotweed rhizomes that have not been
completely killed off may send up new shoots as many as three years later
(Michigan Department of Natural Resources)."

As you can imagine, it is difficult and perhaps almost impossible to get rid
of this plant. The roots need to be killed, not an easy job given how wide and
deep they can be. And you need to get rid of every tiny bit. There should be
laws on controlling its disposal in New York State. Be a good neighbor and if
you are trying to get rid of it on your property, put it in black bags and
take it to be burned.

On a more positive note, while it is not clear that the benefits of the plant
outweigh the disadvantages, there are healers who believe that the stronger
the plant, the stronger its medicine. Steve Brill, in "Foraging New York,"
notes that "it may be helpful in Alzheimer's disease, prostate cancer, Lyme
disease and osteoporosis, but research is still in its early days."

Japanese knotweed is rich in resveratrol. Web MD says resveratrol "has strong
antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. In laboratory studies, it has
prevented the kind of damage that can trigger the cancer process in cells."

Some beekeepers value its late blooming flower as an important source of
nectar for honeybees when little else is flowering. It is so fast growing it
is being considered as a briquette biofuel. And it is edible.

Victoria Quesada is a nature-study enthusiast from Hamilton.

title:
NATURE-STUDY WORKBOOK

A plant that should come with a warning label
html:
I am a great lover of plants which I believe to be the cornerstone of life on this planet. However, fallopia japonica, or Japanese knotweed, is listed by the World Conservation Union as one of the world's most invasive species.

Wikipedia notes that "[t]he invasive root system and strong growth can damage concrete foundations, buildings, flood defenses, roads, paving, retaining walls, and architectural sites." It forms monocultures that completely exclude native species and destroys habitats for local plants and animals and degrades water quality.

The plant is a herbaceous perennial that is a member of the buckwheat family that was introduced to the western world in the mid to late 1800s for its ornamental value. In hindsight, no one should have introduced this plant. Its spread in the United Kingdom has been so pernicious that it is deemed a "controlled waste" which needs to be disposed of in accordance with law.

In the UK, knotweed disclosure is mandatory on all deeds of sale and one cannot obtain a mortgage if the plant is found within a certain number of meters from a residence. Wikipedia notes that it cost 70 million pounds to eradicate knotweed from 10 acres of the London 2012 Olympic Games velodrome and aquatic center.

Japanese knotweed has become a fertile field of civil litigation in the UK with buyers fighting sellers, homeowners fighting contractors and neighbors fighting neighbors (Henry Grabar, Slate.com).

The success of the plant is due to a number of factors. It can survive a wide range of soil types, light (semi-shade and sun), pH and temperatures. It can suppress the growth of competitor plants by releasing toxic chemicals. However, its most fundamental advantage is its rhizome system which can grow 10 feet deep and 23 feet wide (Wikipedia).

"In addition, fragments of both stem and root material can sprout, giving rise to new plants or entire colonies. Knotweed rhizomes that have not been completely killed off may send up new shoots as many as three years later (Michigan Department of Natural Resources)."

As you can imagine, it is difficult and perhaps almost impossible to get rid of this plant. The roots need to be killed, not an easy job given how wide and deep they can be. And you need to get rid of every tiny bit. There should be laws on controlling its disposal in New York State. Be a good neighbor and if you are trying to get rid of it on your property, put it in black bags and take it to be burned.

On a more positive note, while it is not clear that the benefits of the plant outweigh the disadvantages, there are healers who believe that the stronger the plant, the stronger its medicine. Steve Brill, in "Foraging New York," notes that "it may be helpful in Alzheimer's disease, prostate cancer, Lyme disease and osteoporosis, but research is still in its early days."

Japanese knotweed is rich in resveratrol. Web MD says resveratrol "has strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. In laboratory studies, it has prevented the kind of damage that can trigger the cancer process in cells."

Some beekeepers value its late blooming flower as an important source of nectar for honeybees when little else is flowering. It is so fast growing it is being considered as a briquette biofuel. And it is edible.

Victoria Quesada is a nature-study enthusiast from Hamilton.
